title: CVE-2023-27537: HSTS double-free

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

activities.message: Thanks for your report, we will investigate and get back to you as soon as we can.

It seems I did not think of multi-threaded use cases properly when I added support for shared HSTS cache.

I think I need to "fix" this in the short-term by explicitly saying that this does is NOT supported when shared between threads. Similar to the connection cache.

This flaw can make all sorts of accesses to memory that another thread removes or changes, so UaF and double-free does indeed seem likely.

Since this issue needs more than one (cooperating) thread using libcurl within a single process and they need to share HSTS etc, it seems very hard to exploit or trigger in malicious ways. In fact, does it not seem likely to cause a crash fairly easy/quickly and therefore even be unlikely to actually be used in production?

>Since this issue needs more than one (cooperating) thread using libcurl within a single process and they need to share HSTS etc, it seems very hard to exploit or trigger in malicious ways. 

I agree that the conditions for exploitation are difficult.
However, libcurl is very widely used, so I don't think it can be said that there are few.

>In fact, does it not seem likely to cause a crash fairly easy/quickly and therefore even be unlikely to actually be used in production?

This problem does not occur until the HSTS entry is deleted. Considering that the expiration date is updated each time it is accessed, this is a rare case, so it is likely that this issue is not noticed and may be operated in production.
Right... while it can happen even in other situations as well the delete-entry feels like the most likely one to trigger a hit.

> there are few.

Can you explain *one* scenario how an attacker can take advantage of this? I do have a lack of imagination so I often fail to properly see the attacker's view.

>Can you explain one scenario how an attacker can take advantage of this? I do have a lack of imagination so I often fail to properly see the attacker's view.

One example would be a denial of service attack due to an application crash caused by double-free or UAF.
Suppose you have a server program that uses libcurl. If this program has the ability to access any URL specified by the user (client), doing so in large numbers can cause problems.

I think this is a vulnerability. Reasoning:
* In general libcurl claims thread safety `libcurl is thread safe but has no internal thread synchronization.` (1)
* If there are exception to the thread-safety they're explicitly singled out. HSTS caching was not.

I think the severity of this vulnerability is: Low. Reasoning:
* The situation where this can happen in the first place is quite rare.
* The timing has to be really "unlucky" for the issue to trigger as the window between fetching the node pointer and unlinking it from the list is very small. Thread scheduling has to hit this window for the issue to manifest itself.
* Exploitation this for anything but denial of service is difficult as there is no controlled way to massage the heap in any meaningful way to allow RCE or other more serious impacts.

1) https://curl.se/libcurl/c/threadsafe.html

Right, it probably can be abused for a (mild) DOS opportunity but seems to be very hard (not impossible) to use for anything worse.

Going with **Low**.
If this was easier to trigger and/or if there would be practical examples of applications where this has impact I would be thinking more of Medium severity.

This is my initial patch. It only documents this as not working. It would be nice to get this fixed "proper", but I do not have the bandwidth to do this before the pending release.
~~~diff
From eb9db6a615127fcf4cc60ef7b0b60169ee495997 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Daniel Stenberg <daniel@haxx.se>
Date: Thu, 9 Mar 2023 18:01:34 +0100
Subject: [PATCH] CURLSHOPT_SHARE.3: mention that HSTS sharing is not
 thread-safe

---
 docs/libcurl/opts/CURLSHOPT_SHARE.3 | 5 +++--
 1 file changed, 3 insertions(+), 2 deletions(-)

diff --git a/docs/libcurl/opts/CURLSHOPT_SHARE.3 b/docs/libcurl/opts/CURLSHOPT_SHARE.3
index 71320410c..84f5f9659 100644
--- a/docs/libcurl/opts/CURLSHOPT_SHARE.3
+++ b/docs/libcurl/opts/CURLSHOPT_SHARE.3
@@ -54,12 +54,11 @@ handle by default. Note this symbol was added in 7.10.3 but was not
 implemented until 7.23.0.
 .IP CURL_LOCK_DATA_CONNECT
 Put the connection cache in the share object and make all easy handles using
 this share object share the connection cache.
 
-Note that due to a known bug, it is not safe to share connections this way
-between multiple concurrent threads.
+It is not supported to share connections between multiple concurrent threads.
 
 Connections that are used for HTTP/1.1 Pipelining or HTTP/2 multiplexing only
 get additional transfers added to them if the existing connection is held by
 the same multi or easy handle. libcurl does not support doing HTTP/2 streams
 in different threads using a shared connection.
@@ -79,10 +78,12 @@ Added in 7.61.0.
 Note that when you use the multi interface, all easy handles added to the same
 multi handle will share PSL cache by default without using this option.
 .IP CURL_LOCK_DATA_HSTS
 The in-memory HSTS cache.
 
+It is not supported to share the HSTS between multiple concurrent threads.
+
 Added in 7.88.0
 .SH PROTOCOLS
 All
 .SH EXAMPLE
 .nf
-- 
2.39.2

https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/10732

No mention there of the security aspect (until we announce this on March 20).

First shot at an advisory:

CVE-2023-27537: HSTS double-free
================================

Project curl Security Advisory, March 20th 2023 -
[Permalink](https://curl.se/docs/CVE-2023-27537.html)

VULNERABILITY
-------------

libcurl supports sharing HSTS data between separate "handles". This sharing was
introduced without considerations for do this sharing across separate threads
but there was no indication of this fact in the documentation.

Due to missing mutexes or thread locks, two threads sharing the same HSTS data
could end up doing a double-free or use-after-free.

We are not aware of any exploit of this flaw.

INFO
----

This feature was not implemented to support sharing between threads. That is
still left for future improvements. The fix for this issue is therefore a
documentation update clarifying that sharing HSTS between threads is not
expected to work.

CVE-2023-27537 was introduced in [commit
076a2f629119222a](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/076a2f629119222a), shipped
in curl 7.88.0.

CWE-415: Double Free

Severity: Low

Severity is set to Low because

 - Not widely used functionality
 - The timing necessary to trigger this has to match fairly exact
 - Exploitation this for anything but denial of service is difficult

AFFECTED VERSIONS
-----------------

- Affected versions: curl 7.88.0 to and including 7.88.1
- Not affected versions: curl < 7.88.0 and curl >= 8.0.0

libcurl is used by many applications, but not always advertised as such!

THE SOLUTION
------------

A [fix for CVE-2023-27537](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/not-yet)

RECOMMENDATIONS
--------------

 A - Do not share HSTS data between threads

TIMELINE
--------

This issue was reported to the curl project on March 8 2023. We contacted
distros@openwall on March 13, 2023.

libcurl 8.0.0 was released on March 20 2023, coordinated with the publication
of this advisory.

CREDITS
-------

- Reported-by: Hiroki Kurosawa
- Patched-by: Daniel Stenberg

Thanks a lot!
Published. This issue is now eligible for a bounty claim from [IBB](https://hackerone.com/ibb).

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
